speaker: James
text: Orwell's point, "history is written by the winners," isn't just about wartime propaganda, is it? It's a demographic argument, too. Europeans are losing the numbers game, and with it, their history.

speaker: Elena
text: [frustrated] Oh, come on, James. "Losing their history"? That sounds like classic alarmism. History isn't a zero-sum game.

speaker: James
text: Isn't it? After '45, millions of Europeans were forcibly moved. Countries were, in essence, ethnically cleansed. New Germany became more German, Poland more Polish.

speaker: Elena
text: Yes, a terrible refugee crisis. But that created monocultures. What's wrong with challenging those narratives now?

speaker: James
text: Nothing wrong with challenging. But Misan Sagay's talk, for instance, implies a complete reframing. The Burma campaign isn't about white British officers; it's about Indian troops. The 'discovery' of America becomes a shameful epic of genocide.

speaker: Elena
text: And it should be! That's a more complete, more honest history. Why should we cling to a single, often biased, white perspective?

speaker: James
text: Because it's *their* perspective. And for native Europeans, it conveys a sense of worth, as the article puts it. It's a defence.

speaker: Elena
text: So only one group gets to feel worthy? That's not how a diverse society functions, James.

speaker: James
text: [dry] Tell that to the populations of ethnically cleansed states post-1945. Or consider our article on "China Has Many Of The Characteristics Of An Emerging Colonial Power." They certainly don't privilege other narratives.

speaker: Elena
text: That's a different context entirely. We're talking about integrating new perspectives, not imposing one.

speaker: James
text: Orwell said a lie, if recounted often enough, becomes truth. Sagay called Alexandre Dumas 'black.' He had one black grandparent, three white, lived his entire life in France.

speaker: Elena
text: Wait â€” really? I didn't know that specific detail. But it highlights the complexity, doesn't it?

speaker: James
text: Or the blurring of lines. If enough people believe it, does the nuance disappear?

speaker: Elena
text: Perhaps. But for many non-natives, the dominant narrative *is* alien. They need to establish their own value within the European story.

speaker: James
text: Of course they do. But at what cost to the existing narrative? The article highlights the perception of the Holocaust, for instance.

speaker: Elena
text: You mean how some Muslim immigrants see it as exaggerated or, as the article shockingly suggests, as not far enough? That's a serious claim.

speaker: James
text: It's a documented concern. And it's presented not as a native European view. Antisemitism is rising, but 'it is not native Europeans who are pushing this agenda.'

speaker: Elena
text: No, that's completely wrong, and I'll tell you why. To imply that all rising antisemitism in Europe is *solely* from non-native populations is a convenient reading of a complex issue.

speaker: James
text: Not solely, but a significant, often overlooked, component. The data on certain demographics shows a clear correlation.

speaker: Elena
text: Correlation isn't causation. And it risks absolving other sources of antisemitism.

speaker: James
text: It's about the *change* in the narrative landscape, Elena. Who writes history when the composition of the 'winners' shifts?

speaker: Elena
text: Are you saying that a diverse population cannot share a common history?

speaker: James
text: [thoughtful] I'm saying that common histories are forged through shared experience and, yes, often shared ethnicity. When that changes rapidly, the historical anchors become unstable. You said earlier that immigration was a treadmill in another piece, this is related.

speaker: Elena
text: I did. And I meant it in the context of integration, not cultural erasure.

speaker: James
text: But if native Europeans are 'pushed into the shadows' and their heroes co-opted, as the article suggests, is that not a form of erasure? Consider our "Decline of the West" series.

speaker: Elena
text: That's... that's a much harder point to dismiss, I'll admit. The idea that your own cultural touchstones might be reinterpreted or even, well, appropriated, is unsettling.

speaker: James
text: Unsettling, yes. But it's also a rational consequence of demographics. History is written by the dominant group. If that group changes, so does the history.

speaker: Elena
text: So, if the numbers shift, the stories we tell our children about who we are fundamentally change. I hadn't quite connected that. That's actually devastating.

speaker: James
text: [conceding] It's not about good or bad, really. It's about power. A numerical power, in this case. Just like the post-WWII ethnic reshuffling.

speaker: Elena
text: So, the question isn't whether history *should* be rewritten, but whether it *will* be, simply by dint of who is doing the telling?

speaker: James
text: Precisely. And whether native Europeans will be able to recognise themselves in that future history.
